clinical_study.brief_title: The Effects of the Female Hormones on Cerebral Perfusion
clinical_study.official_title: The Effects of the Female Sex Hormones and Hormonal Contraception on Cerebral Perfusion

brief_summary.textblock: Measuring brain perfusion is biased by a inter- and intrasubject variability, caused by physiological and lifestyle factors. In this study, the investigators want to investigate the variations in cerebral perfusion and other brain parameters (grey matter, resting-state brain activity, brain connectivity and white matter diffusion) caused by the female sex hormones and hormonal contraception.

primary_outcome.measure: Regional cerebral perfusion (ml/100g/min): natural versus contraception
primary_outcome.description: Differences in regional perfusion between volunteers of the natural cycle group versus the volunteers using contraception

primary_outcome.measure: Regional cerebral perfusion (ml/100g/min) variations during natural menstrual cycle
primary_outcome.description: Variations in cerebral perfusion during the menstrual cycle: follicular phase versus ovulation versus luteal phase in the natural cycle group, correlated with female hormones measured in blood sample

primary_outcome.measure: Regional cerebral perfusion (ml/100g/min) variations during menstrual cycle using contraception
primary_outcome.description: Variations in cerebral perfusion during the menstrual cycle: pill-week versus pill-free week in the contraception group, correlated with female hormones measured in blood sample

arm_group.description: 15 female volunteers, not using hormonal contraception, will be scanned during 3 menstrual cycles. During each cycle, the volunteers will be scanned 3 times: during the follicular phase, during ovulation and during luteal phase.

15 female volunteers, using hormonal contraception pill Deso 20, will be scanned during 3 menstrual cycles. During each cycle, the volunteers will be scanned 2 times: during the pill-week and during the pill-free week.

intervention.description: Several MRI scan modalities: MPRAGE (structural scan), arterial spin labeling (cerebral perfusion), resting state functional-MRI (fMRI, cerebral activity) and diffusion MRI (white matter diffusion and white matter tracts).
During MRI: heart rate, end-tidal carbon dioxide (CO2), respiratory rate and skin conductance
Blood sample after MRI-session: measurement of hematocrit, hemoglobin, estradiol, progesterone, follicle stimulation hormone and luteinizing hormone.
Measuring blood pressure before and after MRI-scan
Measuring body temperature before and after MRI-scan

Questionnaires at the start of the study on lifestyle. Additionally, a questionnaire before each scan session on the actual state of the volunteer (e.g. mood, caffeine consumption, alcohol, medication, etc.)
Test for pregnancy using a pregnancy dipstick test

study_pop.textblock: 30 healthy young volunteers, either using no hormonal anti-conception, either using Deso20 as anti-conception.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Bachelor or Master student
- Minimum of 3 months not using contraception of using Deso20
Exclusion Criteria:
- No informed consent
- MRI-contraindications
- Claustrophobia
- Pregnancy or breastfeeding
- Chronic diseases and chronic medication use
- Smoker
- Drug use
- Abuse of alcohol and caffeine
